grand-union-canal-braunston.title: Grand Union Canal, Braunston
grand-union-canal-braunston.description: The Grand Union Canal in England is part of the British canal system. Its main line starts in London and ends in Birmingham, stretching for 137 miles (220 km) with 166 locks. It has arms to places including Leicester, Slough, Aylesbury, Wendover and Northampton.

oxford-canal-banbury.title: Oxford Canal, Banbury
oxford-canal-banbury.description: The Oxford Canal is a 78-mile-long (126 km) narrow canal in central England linking Oxford with Coventry via Banbury and Rugby. It connects with the River Thames at Oxford, to the Grand Union Canal at the villages of Braunston and Napton-on-the-Hill, and to the Coventry Canal at Hawkesbury Junction in Bedworth just north of Coventry.

falls-river-abel-tasman-coast-track.title: Falls River, Abel Tasman Coast Track
falls-river-abel-tasman-coast-track.description: An impressive 47-meter long suspension bridge takes you over Falls River. The track takes you through lush coastal forest before leading back to the sea, and the idyllic golden sands of Bark Bay.

bugsworth-basin.title: Bugsworth Basin
bugsworth-basin.description: Bugsworth Basin is a canal basin at the terminus of the Peak Forest Canal. It is located at Buxworth (formerly Bugsworth) in the valley of the Black Brook, close to Whaley Bridge.

sowerby-bridge.title: Sowerby Bridge
sowerby-bridge.description: Sowerby Bridge is a market town that lies within the Upper Calder Valley in the district of Calderdale in the county of West Yorkshire, in northern England.

pontcysyllte-aqueduct.title: Pontcysyllte Aqueduct
pontcysyllte-aqueduct.description: The Pontcysyllte Aqueduct is a navigable aqueduct that carries the Llangollen Canal over the valley of the River Dee in Wrexham County Borough in north east Wales. Completed in 1805, it is the longest and highest aqueduct in Britain, a Grade I Listed Building and a World Heritage Site.

monmouth-brecon-canal-wales.title: Monmouth & Brecon Canal, Wales
monmouth-brecon-canal-wales.description: The Monmouthshire and Brecon Canal runs for 35 miles (56 km) between Brecon and Pontnewydd, Cwmbran. It then continues to Newport, the towpath being the line of communication and the canal being disjointed by obstructions and road crossings. The canal was built between 1797 and 1812 to link Brecon with Newport and the Severn Estuary. The canal in Brecon was redeveloped in the 1990s and is now the site of two mooring basins and the Theatr Brycheiniog.

newark-river-trent.title: Newark, River Trent
newark-river-trent.description: The River Trent is one of the major rivers of England. Its source is in Staffordshire on the southern edge of Biddulph Moor. It flows through the Midlands (forming a once significant boundary between the north and south of England) until it joins theRiver Ouse at Trent Falls to form the Humber Estuary, which empties into the North Sea between Hull and Immingham.

chesterfield-canal-drakeholes.title: Chesterfield Canal, Drakeholes
chesterfield-canal-drakeholes.description: The Chesterfield Canal is in the north of England and it is known locally as 'Cuckoo Dyke'. It was opened in 1777 and ran 46 miles (74 km) from the River Trent at West Stockwith, Nottinghamshire to Chesterfield, Derbyshire. It is currently only navigable as far as Kiveton Park near Rotherham, South Yorkshire, plus an isolated section near Chesterfield.

kennet-avon-canal-pewsey.title: Kennet & Avon Canal, Pewsey
kennet-avon-canal-pewsey.description: Pewsey is a large village, at the centre of the Vale of Pewsey in Wiltshire about 80 miles (130 km) west of London. The Kennet and Avon Canal reached Pewsey in 1810.

regents-canal-little-venice.title: Regent's Canal, Little Venice
regents-canal-little-venice.description: Regent's Canal is a canal across an area just north of central London, England. It provides a link from the Paddington arm of the Grand Union Canal, just north-west of Paddington Basin in the west, to the Limehouse Basin and the River Thames in east London. The canal is 13.8 kilometres (8.6 miles) long

hebden-bridge.title: Hebden Bridge
hebden-bridge.description: Hebden Bridge is a market town within the Metropolitan Borough of Calderdale, in West Yorkshire, England.

market-harborough.title: Market Harborough
market-harborough.description: Market Harborough is a market town within the Harborough district of Leicestershire, England.

river-avon.title: River Avon
river-avon.description: The Avon rises just north of the village of Acton Turville in South Gloucestershire, before flowing through Wiltshire. In its lower reaches from Bath to the Severn Estuary at Avonmouth near Bristol the river is navigable and known as the Avon Navigation.

aldermaston-wharf.title: Aldermaston Wharf
aldermaston-wharf.description: Aldermaston Wharf is a small settlement situated 1.5 miles (2.4 km) north-northwest of Aldermaston in the West Berkshire district, part of the English county of Berkshire. The Kennet and Avon Canal and Great Western Railway pass through it and Aldermaston railway station and Aldermaston Lock are located here.

grand-union-canal-apsley.title: Grand Union Canal, Apsley
grand-union-canal-apsley.description: The Grand Union Canal in England is part of the British canal system. Its main line starts in London and ends in Birmingham, stretching for 137 miles (220 km) with 166 locks. It has arms to places including Leicester, Slough, Aylesbury, Wendover and Northampton.

kennet-avon-canal-newbury.title: Kennet & Avon Canal, Newbury
kennet-avon-canal-newbury.description: The Kennet and Avon Canal is a waterway in southern England with an overall length of 87 miles (140 km),[1] made up of two lengths of navigable river linked by a canal. The name is commonly used to refer to the entire length of the navigation rather than solely to the central canal section.

river-stort-harlow.title: River Stort, Harlow
river-stort-harlow.description: River Stort is a tributary of the River Lea which it joins at Hoddesdon, Hertfordshire at Feildes Weir

marsworth-reservoir.title: Marsworth Reservoir
marsworth-reservoir.description: Marsworth is a village and also a civil parish within Aylesbury Vale district in Buckinghamshire, England.Nearby are three of the four Tring reservoirs, one of which is named Marsworth reservoir.

portland-basin.title: Portland Basin
portland-basin.description: Portland Basin is the location of the Portland Basin Museum, housed within the restored nineteenth century Ashton Canal Warehouse, covering the area's industrial heritage.

stoke-bruerne-grand-union-canal.title: Stoke Bruerne, Grand Union Canal
stoke-bruerne-grand-union-canal.description: Stoke Bruerne is a small village and civil parish in South Northamptonshire, England about 10 miles (16 km) north of Milton Keynes and 7 miles (11 km) south of Northampton.

bradford-on-avon-wharf.title: Bradford-on-Avon Wharf
bradford-on-avon-wharf.description: Bradford on Avon (sometimes Bradford-on-Avon) is a town in west Wiltshire, England with a population of about 9,326. The town's canal, historic buildings, shops, pubs and restaurants make it popular with tourists.

grand-union-canal-watford.title: Grand Union Canal, Watford
grand-union-canal-watford.description: The Grand Union Canal in England is part of the British canal system. Its main line starts in London and ends in Birmingham, stretching for 137 miles (220 km) with 166 locks. It has arms to places including Leicester, Slough, Aylesbury, Wendover and Northampton.

grand-union-canal-cosgrove-and-wolverton.title: Grand Union Canal, Cosgrove and Wolverton
grand-union-canal-cosgrove-and-wolverton.description: The Grand Union Canal in England is part of the British canal system. Its main line starts in London and ends in Birmingham, stretching for 137 miles (220 km) with 166 locks. It has arms to places including Leicester, Slough, Aylesbury, Wendover and Northampton.

bridgwater-docks.title: Bridgwater Docks
bridgwater-docks.description: The Port of Bridgwater is a port, originally located in the town of Bridgwater, Somerset, England. A floating harbour, known as the "docks" was constructed between 1837–1841, when the canal was extended through Bridgwater to the floating harbour.

parent.title: Canals & Rivers
parent.description: Imagery collected by Canal & River Trust. This Collection with feature a beautiful imagery of the canals and rivers flowing through the most beautiful countryside and vibrant cities that England and Wales have to offer.
